did.abstract: Attorney, student and investigator of different cults and cult activities, primarily focusing on the New Age Movement; published writings, collected topical files; cassette sound recordings, and videotapes.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received from Constance Cumbey (donor no. 9446) in various accessions, 2004 and 2007..

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are not expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright held jointly by Constance Cumbey and the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Constance E. Cumbey papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Constance Elizabeth Cumbey, nee Butler, was born 29 February 1944 in Fort Wayne, Indiana. Cumbey was raised as a Seventh Day Adventist and as an adult converted to the Baptist faith. She completed her pre-law studies at Michigan State University and Wayne State University. In 1975 she received her juris doctor degree from Detroit College of Law. Constance Cumbey's professional activities include working as a legislative analyst for William A. Ryan, speaker of the Michigan House of Representatives, from 1969 to 1970, being employed as a consultant to the Governmental Efficiency Subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee for the Michigan State Senate, serving as corresponding secretary and treasurer of the National Association of Women Lawyers, and acting as chairperson of the Family Law Committee of the General Practice Section of the American Bar Association. She has continuously served by appointment on the Public Advisory Committee of the State Bar of Michigan since 1978. Cumbey has been active in the litigation, criminal, family law, and general practice sections of the American Bar Association. In 2003 she was appointed to serve a three year term to plan future State Bar meetings by the State Bar of Michigan. From 1992 to 2004 Constance Cumbey hosted Law Talk, a call-in radio program on a Christian radio station.

Between the years 1981 and 1988 Constance Cumbey ceased her law practice and dedicated her life to investigating the New Age Movement. Cumbey's The Hidden Dangers of the Rainbow, published in 1983, was a best-selling Christian book and was one of the first works to criticize the movement from a fundamentalist Christian perspective. A sequel, A Planned Deception: The Staging of a New Age Messiah, was published in 1985. She also circulated a newsletter titled Constance Cumbey's New Age Monitor.

scopecontent.p: The Constance Cumbey collection consists of her publications, research files and other material related to her investigations of alleged connections between New Age cults and the New World Order and various politicians, organizations and institutions. There are also files documenting her interest in Christian fundamentalism and prominent evangelists and their ties to cults. The collection has been divided into three series: Topical Files (three subseries), Personal Files, and Other Media.
Topical Files makes up the bulk of the collection with three subseries of files, each arranged alphabetically, but kept separate because of different dates of accessions.

This first of three Topical Files subseries has been designated Group 1 (16 linear feet; bulk dates 1985-1995) and consists of a wide variety of collected material on the New Age Movement. Due to the success of her first book The Hidden Dangers of the Rainbow Constance Cumbey established a wide correspondence network which enabled her to build an impressive collection of ephemeral materials and independent publications -- material which is sometimes referred to as "gray literature" or "fugitive literature." The series contains general information about the New Age Movement such as pamphlets and magazines regarding globalization, alternative religions, spirituality, alternative lifestyles, technology, Afrocentrism, feminism, and foreign politics. There is also information on known New Age leaders Benjamin Creme and the Maitreya movement, Robert Muller and AD 2000 movement, and Bubba Free John and the Free Communion Church. A strength of this series is the large amount of information about education in Michigan and how the New Age Movement may have influenced the creation of new educational measures such as the Malcolm X Academy in Detroit, the Michigan Model, outcome based education, and home schooling.

scopecontent.p: This topical files subseries, designated Group 2, is the largest of the three subject subseries (62 linear feet; bulk dates 1980-1988). The content is much the same as Group 1, except that the files date somewhat earlier and have a broader range of subject headings. Additional topics covered here include the ministry of Pat Robertson, the Theosophical Society, Freemasonry, and a variety of conspiracy topics such as the "cashless society." The Lucis Trust, which was founded by occultist Alice Bailey and has consultant status with the United Nations Economic and Social Council, is also prominently featured in this series. Materials related to Nazism, White Supremacy, and the Christian Identity Movement are also present. Another strength of this group of files, as well as Group 1, is the topic of how the New Age Movement may have influenced the creation of new educational measures. Files about AIDS (some materials were filed under Homosexuality) capture the reactions and responses to the pandemic as it was unfolding in the early 1980's.

scopecontent.p: This topical files subseries is the smallest but with the most currently dated material (5 linear feet; bulk dates 1990-2000). File headings are similar to the other two groups.

scopecontent.p: The Constance Cumbey Personal series (1 linear foot) is divided into five subseries: Correspondence (many of the topical files also contain correspondence); Ephemera, which includes biographical statements, newspaper clippings, and public appearances; Interview Transcripts; Manuscripts; and Publications, which contains the two books that Constance Cumbey wrote about the New Age movement (as well as two foreign language translations), miscellaneous articles and presentations, and her New Age Monitor newsletter.

scopecontent.p: The Other Media series (3 linear feet) contains CD-ROM's, twenty-six VHS videotapes, and 145 audio cassette tapes. Most of the VHS tapes contain presentations and debates that Cumbey gave and participated in at locations throughout the country during the 1980's where she discussed her books and the New Age Movement. These tapes shed light on why Constance Cumbey spent many years studying the movement and why she views it as a destructive force in Christianity and in modern American society. A number of the tapes are recordings of television programs or local news programs from the 1980's and the early 1990's that discuss New Age themes. Many of these taped television programs contain brief interviews with Cumbey. There are also a few tapes that focus on a debate between Cumbey and Christian Mystic Elizabeth MacDonald Burrows on the topic of religion and the New Age Movement. A majority of the audiocassettes are recordings of Law Talk, a call-in radio program hosted by Constance Cumbey, which contains discussion of both legal and religious topics. The CD-ROM contains a powerpoint presentation made by Cumbey that highlights the political activity of European Union Secretary-General Javier Solana. She makes clear her opinion that Solana has ties to the New World Order by discussing his Marxist past, his attacks against the religion of conviction, and his plans to achieve a stronger and dominant Europe.

odd.p: (Tape contains news stories on Malcolm X Academy, terrorism, NAFTA, and Rodney King)
